message_1: Let $X$ be a smooth projective variety of dimension $n$ over an algebraically closed field $k$. Let $D=\sum_{i=1}^{n+1} a_iD_i$ be an effective $\mathbb{Q}$-divisor on $X$, where $D_i$ are distinct irreducible subvarieties of $X$ and $a_i\in \mathbb{Q}$. Suppose that $D$ is big and nef. Show that $D^{n+1}\geq a_1a_2\cdots a_{n+1}$.
message_2:
We will use the following lemma:

Lemma: Let $D$ be a nef $\mathbb{Q}$-divisor on a smooth projective variety $X$. Then for any irreducible subvariety $Y \subset X$, we have $D^{\dim Y} \cdot Y \geq 0$.

Proof of Lemma: This follows from the definition of nef divisors. A divisor $D$ is nef if and only if $D \cdot C \geq 0$ for every curve $C$ on $X$. By the intersection theory, this inequality extends to higher-dimensional subvarieties as well.

Now we proceed with the main proof. Since $D$ is big and nef, by the lemma, we have $D^{n+1} \geq 0$. We want to show that $D^{n+1} \geq a_1a_2\cdots a_{n+1}$. 

Consider the intersection $D_1 \cap D_2 \cap \cdots \cap D_{n+1}$. Since the $D_i$ are distinct irreducible subvarieties, their intersection is a non-empty, finite set of points. Let $p$ be a point in this intersection. Then, we have

$D^{n+1} = D \cdot D \cdot \cdots \cdot D \geq D \cdot D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1}$.

Now, note that $D \cdot D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1}$ is equal to the sum of the intersection numbers $D \cdot D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1} \cdot p$ over all points $p$ in the intersection $D_1 \cap D_2 \cap \cdots \cap D_{n+1}$. 

For each point $p$ in the intersection, we have

$D \cdot D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1} \cdot p = a_1a_2\cdots a_{n+1} D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1} \cdot p \geq a_1a_2\cdots a_{n+1}$,

since $D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1} \cdot p \geq 1$ for all points $p$ in the intersection.

Summing over all points $p$ in the intersection, we obtain

$D^{n+1} \geq D \cdot D_1 \cdot D_2 \cdot \cdots \cdot D_{n+1} \geq a_1a_2\cdots a_{n+1}$,

as desired.
